181.text:
I was heavily dyslexic, I still am, and school
life was pretty tough from that point of view,

186.text:
struggling to read and write, of being put
into the sort of lower sets of all the classes

193.text: apart from sport, which I was reasonable at.

196.text:
But I went to a small comprehensive school,
and the head of the English department had

202.text:
One was rugby and the other was rowing, and
he asked me if I would like to try the sport

207.text: of rowing at the age of 13, nearly 14.

210.text:
And to me, great, once a week, games lessons,
I could leave school, go out on the river.

216.text:
Unfortunately, after two or three weeks I
started going down every day after school,

221.text: and it sort of became my life in some ways.

224.text:
And at a very young age is that, from rowing
at Marlow Rowing Club, it's not that far away

229.text:
from here, about a half an hour's drive from
where we are now, where I live, is that there

234.text: were people that were on the national team.

235.text:
We had three coaches at Marlow Rowing Club
that were part of national team, and they

239.text: were saying you could be world champion.

242.text: You are capable of one day being a world champion.

244.text: And I said that sounds great.

245.text: Yeah, that gives me a little focus.

248.text:
It was one of the best things that happened
to me but also one of the worst things that

252.text:
happened because I believed one day I was
going to be world champion.

255.text:
And I thought, well, why not world champion,
why not Olympic champion.

259.text:
So I started setting my goals from that point
of view.

261.text:
But I honestly believed that one day it was
going to happen.

264.text:
All I didn't know is which year it was going
to be.

266.text: I felt my name was engraved on the trophy.

269.text:
It was just going to decide what year it was
going to be.

271.text:
So you sort of bide your time, you follow
the coaching process of what you are asked

276.text:
We didn't have any history, recent history
of performance at that time, so you are following

282.text: a path of a team that hasn't been succeeding.

286.text:
And I went to one world championships and
performed really badly and that was the best

290.text:
thing that ever happened to me because I felt,
well, other people think I am capable of doing

294.text:
this, I think I am capable of doing this,
why isn't it happening?

297.text:
And we reevaluated the whole process and looked

302.text:
hard enough, we weren't taking it professionally
enough.

305.text: And so sort of changed the attitude.

307.text: And within nine months became Olympic champion.

You clearly had the confidence and self-belief,

326.text:
>>Steve Redgrave: When you're trying to get

333.text: So there are books out there.

334.text:
There are stories of how to be able to get

338.text:
So actually getting there is relatively easy,

343.text:
Once you get there to try and get to a new
level that no one's ever performed at before,

348.text:
that's where the book has to be ripped up
and start again.

352.text:
I suppose the process that I started to develop
was we all know about personal bests and you

359.text: set yourself targets to get to.

361.text: Not everyone can be Olympic champion.

363.text: Not everyone can be the best in their field.

365.text: But we can all be better than we are.

367.text:
We can all improve and look for our own personal
bests.

370.text:
I think what really sums this up to me -- it
is a very old story, but a guy called John

374.text: Naber, who is an American swimmer.

376.text: He competed at the Munich Games 1972.

380.text:
He was part of the American relay team in
the swimming competition and helped that team

385.text:
qualify for the final but didn't swim in the
final himself.

388.text:
He came out of those games, he thought, "How
can I get to the next level?

393.text: I want to win that gold medal.

394.text:
I want to be part of that relay team in '76
in Montreal."

400.text:
So what he did is he actually looked back
through the history books and saw a steady

404.text:
improvement and almost could predict a time
that he felt he had to do to win that gold

409.text:
medal in four years' time in the individual
event, not just the team event.

414.text: He predicted a time of 55.5 seconds.

416.text: That's what he had to do.

417.text: His discipline was the 100 meters backstroke.

419.text:
The problem was his personal best at that
time was 59.5 seconds.

423.text:
He had to go four seconds quicker over 100
meters swimming on his back.

427.text: He thought, "I can't do that, it is impossible."

430.text:
By setting himself these targets sort of blew
himself away that he couldn't achieve it.

436.text:
But then he started thinking a little bit
more laterally about it, thinking, I don't

439.text:
have to swim that time today, tomorrow, this
year.

442.text: I have got four years to do it.

444.text: That's a second improvement in every year.

446.text: He trained for ten months every year.

448.text:
1/10th of a second improvement in a month's
training.

452.text: That's 1/300th improvement in a day's training.

456.text:
He used to train for four hours a day every
day during that training period.

461.text: So that's 1/1200th second of an improvement.

465.text: It takes an eye to blink 5/1200ths of a second.

467.text:
He is looking for 1/5 of a eye blink improvement
in an hour's training.

473.text:
There is something about defining that will
make you go a little bit quicker.

476.text:
The difficult thing is you go do that every
hour of every day of every month of every

482.text:
Obviously, the moral of the story is he did
get to the games.

485.text:
He was part of the relay team that took the
gold medal and swum in that final.

489.text:
And he made the final of the individual event
where he was racing two-time Olympic champion,

493.text:
world record holder and that sort of process
and took the gold medal in a time of 59.49

503.text:
So what seemed to be impossible, he broke
it down, looked at it very laterally in a

507.text:
different way from more ways of looking at
it.

509.text:
In some ways, that's what you have got to
do.

512.text: Those targets are great to be able to do that.

515.text:
When I retired, I then started raising money
for charity.

519.text:
And I set up my own charitable trust to try

524.text: I thought -- I remember that story.

525.text: I'm going to break it all down.

527.text:
Breaking it down to 20,000 pounds a week every
week for five years having two weeks off each

532.text: year, it is not going to happen.

533.text:
We actually looked at it from a different
point of view, focused on big occasions to

537.text: try to raise a lot of money.

539.text:
Really what you have to do is to look at the
tasks you have, look at the way your process

543.text:
of doing it, and then maybe turn it on its
head and look at it in different ways.

547.text:
To get to the next level, you just go look
at all the tools you can offer in that direction

553.text:

563.text:

you were still capable of doing what you wanted

568.text:
>>Steve Redgrave: Once I was diagnosed, I
thought it was my international career over.

570.text: That was three years before my last Olympics.

573.text:
I had a grandfather that had diabetes in his
late 60s, early 70s and didn't survive much

579.text: I knew it was a pretty serious condition.

581.text:
So I knew that had to be monitored and being
an Olympic top athlete is not going to happen.

587.text:
So I went to the consultation stage, that
I was expecting my consultant is now going

592.text: to tell me I can't do what I was doing.

595.text: I was with him for three hours.

596.text:
At the end of it, he said, Well, I don't see
any reason why you can't achieve your dreams

601.text:
I thought, if he thinks I can do it, I would
give it my best shot.

604.text: He did say it was going to be hard.

606.text:
He didn't tell me that he didn't have a clue
of how we were going to go about it and what

611.text:
He scoured the Internet in a few hours before
I came and saw him.

617.text:
So his vision, it wasn't until after we achieved
what we did he told me the reality that he

623.text:
didn't have a clue of how we were going to
do it.

625.text:
I suppose it was his attitude that I felt
that diabetes had to live with me, not me

630.text:
That was a quite good way of taking on the
challenge in some ways.
